bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: iskwêwak êyôkô : mitâtaht iskwêwak , piyêsiwak , iskwêwak , êkwah ôhtâwiyiwâwa minah okâwiyiwâwa ôk îskwêwak , êh-okimâwiyit ôhtâwiyiwâwa . This is about some women: ten women, Thunderer-Woman, and their father and mother; and their father was a chief.

êkwah ôtah , askîhk otah , êkotah oskinîkiwak mîna mitâtaht , mîn êyakonik owîtisânihtocik , mâka nam âwiya okâwîwâwa ; ôhtâwîwâwah minah nam âwiya . And here on earth were also ten youths, who, in the same way, were brothers, but these had no mother; and they had no father.
nam âwiya kotakah ayîsiyiniwah ayâyiwah kisiwâk . no other people dwelt near there.
êkwah ôki ispimihk iskwêwak , itêh k-ayâcik , misâw ôtênaw êwako . And up above, where those women dwelt, that was a large town.
êwakonik ôki iskwêwak , pêyak omisimâw macihkihkwêwis isiyîhkâsôw . Among those women, the oldest of the sisters was called Silly Maiden.
êkosi awa osîmimâw , aw ôskinîkiskwêw miyosiw . And the youngest was a pretty maid.
êkosi êkwah kotakak ôk ôskinîkiwak mitâtaht k-êhtasicik , êwako ostêsimâw macihkiwis ; And likewise, among those others, those ten young men, the oldest was Matchihkiwis;
kêyâpic aw ôsîmimâw , aw ôskinîkiw miyosiw . and, again, the youngest brother was a handsome youth.
êkosi oskinîkiwak ôki namoya kiskêyimêwak iskwêwa nânitaw kit-âyâyit , mînah kotakah ayîsiyiniwah . Now, those young men did not know that there were anywhere any women, or any other people at all.
pêyakwanohk êy-ayâcik ôk ôskinîkiwak , pisisik mâcîwak kahkiyaw ôk ôskinîkiwak . Those youths stayed always in that one place, and all of them did nothing but hunt.

kîtahtawê ôma êh-mâcîcik mâna , êka âwiyah êh-apiyit , aw ôskinîkiw osîmimâw êyako mânah nîkân takosin . Then, as time went on, and they hunted, and none of them stayed at home, then that youngest brother was always the first to get home.
êkosi kahkiyaw nâh-nâway takosinwak . After him they would all come, one after the other.
kîtahtawê êh-takohtêt aw ôskinîkiw , kâ-wâpahtahk mistah êy-astêyikih mihtah . Once upon a time, when that youth came home, he saw a great amount of firewood lying there.
tâpiskôc awiya ê-kîh-takohtêyit , itêyihtam , êh-takohtêt . Exactly as if someone had come there it seemed to him, as he approached.

mistahi miywêyihtam ,
mâskôc awiyak pîhcayihk tit-apiw , ê-têyihtahk . He was very glad, thinking, “Perhaps there will be someone within.”
êh-pîhtokêt , nam âwiyah wâpamêw . When he went inside, he saw no one.
êkosi wayawîw , ta-papâmohtêt , ka-wâpahtahk itah êsah ê-kîh-pimohtêyit iskwêwah . So he went out and walked round the place, and there he saw that a woman must have gone by.
êkwah mitihtêw itêh êh-kîh-nikohtêyit ; nam âwiya wâpamêw . Then he followed her tracks to where she had gathered wood; he saw no one.
kâwih kîwêw ; pîhtokêw , êkwah êh-kotawêt , ê-wîh-paminawasot . He went back again; he went indoors and built his fire, to cook the meal.

êh-kîsi-kotawêt , ohtapiwinihk êh-apit , kîtahtawê kêkway kâ-kiskêyihtahk itâmihk êh-astêyikih otanâskânihk . When he had made his fire and was sitting on his couch, soon he knew that there were some things under his mat.
êkosi êh-pâskinahk , kâ-wâpahtahk maskisinah . When he uncovered them, he behold some moccasins.
otinam , êh-wâ-wâpahtahk ; mistahi miywâsiniyiwah . He took them and looked at them; they were very pretty.
miywêyihtam ; nahastâw . He was glad; he put them carefully away.

omis îtwêw :
iskwêw êcik ânih kâ-kîh-takohtêt ! itêyihtam ; He said, “And so a woman has come here!” he thought;
namoya ta-wâpahtamwak nistêsak , itêyihtam . “My brothers had better not see them,” he thought.
êh-kocih-postiskahk , pôtih miyoskam . When he tried them on, why, they fitted him well.
êkosi êkwah kotakah ostêsah kâ-tah-takohtêyit , piyisk kahkiyaw takohtêyiwah ostêsah ; And then his brothers began to arrive, one after the other, until all of them had come;
mâkah namoya wî-wîhtamawêw . but he did not care to tell them about it.
êkosi mînah ê-kîh-nipâcik , êh-wâpahk , kîkisêpâ sipwêhtêw ôw oskinîkiw , êh-mâcît . Then, when they had slept, on the next day, early in the morning that youth went out to hunt.

kotakak mînah âsk-âskaw sipwêhtêwak , namoya mâna êh-wîcêhtocik ôk ôskinîkiwak kâ-mâcîcik , kahkiyaw êh-pâ-pêyakocik , miyâcîtwâwi . The others, too, one after the other at intervals, set out, for those young men did not keep each other company when they hunted, but did their hunting each by himself.

êkosi êkwah aw ôskinîkiw ,
mâskôc ê-wîh-wîkimit awa iskwêw kâ-kîh-takosihk , itêyihtam . Then that youth thought, “Perhaps it is because she wants to marry me that this woman has come here.”

itêh êh-nipahât mostoswah , êkwah otêyaniy , êkwah itah êh-miywâsiniyik wiyâs , êkwah pêyak opêminak , êwako otinam , êkwah omâw , êh-kîwêt . Where he killed a buffalo, he took the tongue, and the best parts of the flesh, and one thigh-bone, and the smallest stomach, and went home.

seg.q: mâskôc takohtêcih ana iskwêw , ta-mîciw ômah omâw ;
seg.gloss: “Perhaps, if that woman comes, she will eat this stomach;

p.seg: mînah ta-pâstaham om opêminak , ta-mîcit , êy-itêyihtahk , kîwêw . and she will split this thigh-bone and eat it,” he thought as he went home.
êkwah kisiskâhtêw , ê-wîh-kakwê-kêsiskawât oskinîkiskwêwah , êy-itêyihtahk . He walked fast, thinking to come upon the young woman while she was there.
pôtih êh-otâkosiniyik , êh-takohtêt , âsay mînah mihtah wâpahtam mihcêt êh-astêyikih . Then, towards evening, when he arrived, again he saw a great amount of firewood lying there.
wâpahtam êh-pikihtêyik wîkiwâw . He saw smoke rusing from their tipi.
mâskôc apiw , itêyihtam . “Perhaps she is there,” he thought.

êh-pîhtokêt , nam âwiyah wâpamêw , êsah kâh-wêpâstakahikêyit . When he entered, he saw no one, but it was plain that someone had swept. LB on {kâh-wêpâstakahikêyit}: Error for {kâh-wâpahtakahikêyit}, or a different word?
miywêyihtam . He was glad.
êkwah pônam , ê-wîh-paminawasot . Then he fed his fire, to cook their meal.

êkwah êh-apit , êh-paminawasot , âsay mîna kêkway itêyihtam itah kâ-kiy-astêyikih maskisinah . Then, as he sat there while cooking, it seemed to him that again there was something where the moccasins had been.
êh-otinahk , mîn êyakonih maskisinah . When he took it out, this too was a pair of moccasins.
âsay mîna miywêyihtam , êh-wâ-wâpahtahk . Again he was glad, as he looked at them.
mistahi miywâsiniyiwa , êh-pîmikitêyikih . They were very pretty, embroidered with quill-work.

êkosi astâw ,
namoya ta-wâpahtamwak nistêsak , êh-itêyihtahk . He put them away, thinking “My brothers had better not see them.”
êkwah ôki oskinîkiwak êh-tâh-takohtêcik , wâpahtamwak mihtah mihcêt . Then, when those young men arrived, one after the other, they saw a great amount of firewood.

miywêyihtamwak ,
tâpwê kiyipah mistahi nikohtêw , êh-itêyimâcik osîmiwâwa . They were glad to think of their younger brother, “Truly, in a short time he gathers a great deal of wood.”

awah ostêsimâw , êwako macihkiwis , omis îtwêw :
tâpwê nimiywêyihtên mihtah mistahi êh-astêkih , itwêw . The oldest one, Matchihkiwis, said, “Truly I am glad that there is so much firewood.” book has exclamation mark instead of colon
êhag , itwêwak oskinîkiwak . “Yes, indeed,” said the young man.
êkosi namoya wîh-wîhtam aw oskinîkiw . Then that youth did not care to tell what had happened.
êkosi êkwah tipiskâyiw mîna . Then it grew dark again.
ê-kîh-mîcisocik , êh-ay-apicik , kontah êh-âh-âcimocik , piyisk kawisimowak . When they had eaten, and had sat a while, telling all kinds of stories, they went to bed.
hâw , kiyipah nika-waniskân , itêyihtam aw oskinîkiw ; “Now then, I shall get up early,” thought the youth;
nika-sipwêhtân kiyipah , êh-itêyihtahk . “I shall set out early,” was his thought.
tâpwêw kiyipah waniskâw , ê-wîh-mâcît . So he got up early, to go hunting.
tâpwê ê-kîh-mîcisot , wawêyîw , êh-mâcît . When he had eaten, he made ready to go hunting.
mitonih miywêyihtam . He was very happy.
mâskôc ê-wîh-wîkimit away iskwêw kâ-takosihk , itêyihtam . “Perhaps it is because she wants to marry me that this woman has come here,” he thought.
êkosi itê êh-nipahât mostoswah , êkwah otinam itah ê-miywâsiniyik wiyâs . So then, where he killed a buffalo, he took the best parts of the meat.

êkwah êh-kîwêt , pâh-pimipahtâw ,
mâskôc nika-wâpamâw , êh-itêyihtahk . When he went home, he kept running, for he thought, “Perhaps I shall see her.”
cîki êh-ihtât wîkiwâhk , kâ-wâpahtahk mistah êh-pikihtêyik wîkiwâw . When he had got close to their tipi, he saw that much smoke was rising from it.
ê-takohtêt , mistahi wâpahtam mihtah êh-astêyik . When he arrived, he saw that much firewood lay there.

êh-pîhtokêt , nam âwiya wâpamêw , êsah mitonih kâh-wêpahtakahikêyit , mînah otanâskâniwâwa êsah êh-pahpawahamiyit ; mîn êsah kâh-paminawasoyit astêyiwa . When he entered, he saw no one, though it was plain that someone had swept the place clean, and had brushed out their mats; and there was a meal which she must have cooked.
sôskwâc mîcisôw . He ate right away.
âsay mîna kâ-wâpahtahk kêkway êh-astêyikih . êw-otinahk , âsay mînah maskisinah . When again he saw somethings lying there, and took them up, again it was moccasins. merged 24.22.7 and 24.22.8
mtoni miywêyihtam . He was very glad.
hâw , namoya nka-wîhtamawâwak nistêsak , itêyihtam . “Now, I shall not tell my brothers about it,” he thought.
pôtih êh-otâkosihk , kâ-tâh-takohtêyit ostêsah . Toward evening his brothers arrived, one after the other.

êkwah omis îtwêw aw ostêsimâw :
tâpwê kikiyipîn , mihtah êh-otinaman , itêw osîma . Then the oldest brother said, “Really, you are very quick about getting faggots,” he said to his brother.
êhag , ayisk kiyipah nikîh-takosinin , itêw . “Yes, for, you see, I got home early,” he told him.
êkosi kotakak mîn ôki ê-kîh-mîcisocik , êkosi atih-tipiskâyiw . Then, by the time the others had eaten their meal, it was getting dark.
êkwah ay-apiwak , êh-âcimocik , ômah kâ-kîh-mâcîcik êwako êh-âcimocik , êh-pâ-pâhpicik . Then they sat there a while, telling stories, telling about the hunting they had done, and laughing.
êkosi mînah wîpac nka-sipwêhtân , itêyihtam aw ôskinîkiw . “This time, too, I shall set out early,” he told him.
kiyipah kawisimôw . Quickly he went to bed.
êkosi kahkiyaw kawisimôwak , êh-nipâcik . Then they all went to bed and slept.
pôtih kiyipah waniskâw aw oskinîkiw , êh-paminawasot . That youth got up early, and cooked his food.
êkosi kahkiyaw waniskâwak , êkwah êh-mîcisocik . Then they all arose and ate.
mayaw êh-kîsi-mîcisocik , wawêyîw , êh-mâcît aw oskinîkiw . As soon as they had eaten, that youth made ready to go hunting.
êh-kîh-sipwêhtêt , êkoyikohk kahkiyaw sipwêhtêwak , êh-mâcîcik . When he had departed, then they all went out to hunt.

itêh êh-minahot aw osîmimâw , mistahi wiyâs kîwêhtatâw , kiyipah ê-wîh-kakwê-takohtêt wîkiwâhk . From where he killed his game, the youngest brother took home a great deal of meat, and he meant to try to get home quickly.
tâpwê cîk êy-ihtât , wâpahtam mistah êh-pikihtêyik wîkiwâw ; And truly, when he got near, he saw much smoke rising from their tipi;
êkwah tâpwê mistahi wâpahtam mihtah . and truly, he saw much firewood.
êh-ati-takohtêt wîkiwâhk , kâ-matwê-kitowêhtâyit pîhcâyîhk awiyah . When he went on and approached the tent, there was someone noisily carrying on within.
êh-pîhtokêt , êh-nanâtawâpit , kâ-wâpamât iskwêwah . When he entered, as he looked about, there he saw a woman.
pôtih mitoni miywâsiniyiwa otanâskâniyiwa êh-pêtâyit . Lo, very beautiful were her mats which she had brought.
miywêyihtam êh-nahapîstawât . He was happy to go and sit by her.

sêmâk omaskisinah kâh-kêtikonamiyiwa , kotakah êh-postaskisinahikot , êh-itikot ,
tâpwê mitoni yâhkih kikaskêyihtên , ê-wîh-wâpamiyan , ê-kiskêyihtaman ôtah ê-kîh-nakatamân ta-kikaskisinêyan , êh-itikot . At once she took off his moccasins and put others on his feet, and said to him, “Truly, you were very sad, of late, with longing to see me, when you knew that I had left those moccasins here for you to wear.”
êhag , itwêw awoh oskinîkiw ; “Yes,” said the youth;

omisi itwêw :
ayisk namoya kiyipah kitakohtân , kayâs êh-takohtêyin ta-kî-kisâtaman sêmâk , itêw ; “For indeed, not promptly have you come, seeing that you might have stayed at once, when long ago you arrived,” he told her;
kontah kikîh-kâh-kîwân , itêw . “Needlessly you have been going back and forth,” he told her.

âyisk ,
pitah ntaw-âh-atoskê , êy-isit nôhtâwiy , êkosi itwêw aw ôskinîkiskwêw . “It was because my father told me, ‘First go there several times to work’,” said that young woman.
êkosi êkwah mîcisôwak . Then they ate their meal.

êh-kîsi-mîcisocik , kâ-takohtêcik ôki kotakak oskinîkiwak , piyîhtokêtwâwi , wiyâpamâtwâwi ôh ôskinîkiskwêwah . When they had eaten, then, when those other young men arrived, as they entered and saw that young woman,
mistahi miywêyihtamwak . they were very glad.
nanâskomôwak êh-ôwîtimocik . They gave thanks that they had a sister-in-law.
aw ôstêsimâw macihkiwis nâway takosin . That oldest brother, Matchihkiwis, came last.
êh-pîhtokêt , êh-wâpamât ôhiy iskwêwa , mistahi nanâskomôw . When he entered and saw the woman, he was delighted.

hay hay ! itwêw ;
êkwah , êkâ êkwah kê-kaskikwâtisôyahk ! itwêw . “Splendid!” he said; “So now we won't have to sew for ourselves!” he said.
êkosi miywêyihtamwak . So they were happy.
êkotê tahto-kîsikâw mâcîwak . Then every day they went hunting.

omis îtwêw aw îskwêw :
hâw , nîtimotik , kâ-nipahâyêkok mostoswak , mistahi pêtâk wiyâs . Thus spoke that woman; “Now, my brothers-in-law, when you kill buffalo, bring home much meat.
mîna askêkinwah êkâ wiya wêpinamok ; êkwah nama kêkway kik-ômaskisininâwâw , itêw aw îskwêw . And do not throw away the hides; otherwise you will have nothing for moccasins,” she told them.
âhag , itwêwak ôk ôskinîkiwak . “Very well,” said the young men.
miyâcîtwâwi , âh-iyawis pêsiwêwak , ômah wiyâs . When they hunted, they always brought the animals entire, for meat.

miywêyihtam ôw ôskinîkiskwêw êh-atoskêt , pahkêkinwah êy-osîhtât , mîna kâhkêwakwah êh-nîmâwinihkêt , piyisk kahkiyaw ôhi nâpêwah omaskisiniyiwa êh-osihtât , piyis mînah otayôwinisiyiwa êh-osihtât pahkêkinwa ohcih , The young woman was happy at her work, preparing leather, and making stores of dried meat, and in time making moccasins for all those men, and clothes out of the hides,
mâka mîkisah êh-kikamohât otâsiyihk mînah oskotâkayihk . and, what was more, putting beadwork on their leggings and their coats.
mistahi miywêyihtamwak ôk ôskinîkiwak , iyikohk êh-pamihikocik wîtimôwâwah . Those young men were very glad to have their sister-in-law take such good care of them.
mistahi kitimêkêyimêwak ôh îskwêwah . They were very fond of the woman.
mistahi atoskêw aw îskwêw . She worked very hard.
êkwah kinwêsk êh-ayât awa iskwêw , kîtahtawê awah macihkiwis akâwâtêw ôhih oskinîkiskwêwah . [no translation]
kiskêyihtam aw oskinîkiskwêw êh-itêyihtamiyit ôhi wîtimwah . [no translation]
piyis kinwêsk ayâw êkotah . Time passed; she had been there a long while.

êkwah kahkiyaw êh-mâcîcik , macihkiwis awa kâ-têtipêwêt itah mâna êh-nikohtêyit wîtimwa , ômisi êh-itêyihtahk :
nik-ôwîcimosin nîtim , êy-itêyihtah , êkotah ê-kâsôhtawât . Then, when all were hunting, Matchihkiwis went circling about the place where his sister-in-law was wont to gather firewood, and this was his thought: [no translation] he thought, as he hid from her there.
êkwah awa aw îskwêw êh-ntawi-nikohtêt , kâ-wâpamât wîtimwa êh-pêw-otihtikot . Then, when that woman went to gather faggots, there she saw her husband's brother coming toward her.
hâw , nîtim , miywêyimin ! itwêw macihkiwis . [no translation]
kimiywêyimitin , itwêw aw iskwêw ; [no translation]
mâka k-êtêyihtaman wiy êwako nisâkwêyimon ; osâm nisâkihâw kisîm , itêw . [no translation]

ômis îtwêw awah awah macihkiwis :
hê , nîtim , pêyakwâw pikoh ka-wîcêtin . [no translation]
itâp namoya ka-wîhtamawâw nisîm , itêw . [no translation]
nisâkwêyimon , nîtim , itik ôh iskwêwah . [no translation]
êkosi nawatinêw , ê-mâsihât , ê-wîh-kakwê-kawipitât . [no translation]
namoya sâkohêw ôh iskwêwah . [no translation]

piyisk pimwêw oskâtiyihk ,
nka-sâkohâw , êh-itêyihtahk . [no translation]
mâka namoya sâkohêw . [no translation]
piyisk êkos îsi pônihêw , êh-sipwêhtêt , êh-mâcît . [no translation]
êkosi awah iskwêw êkotah ohci sipwêhtêw , êh-kîwêt , êh-nêpêwisit , wîtimwah ômah êh-tôtâkot . [no translation]
hâta namoya ê-sâkohikot , mâka nêpêwisiw ; êk ôhci k-ô-sipwêhtêt . [no translation] that was why she went away.
êkwah ôk ôskinîkiwak , êh-takohtêt awa wiyîwit , pôtih âstawiyiw wîkiwâw . Then, as for those young men, when he came home whose wife she was, lo, their tent was without a fire.
namoya wâpamêw owîkimâkanah . He did not see his wife.
tânêhkih êtokê êkâ k-ôh-apit ! itêyihtam . “I wonder why she is not here?” he thought.
êh-ntonawât , namoya miskawêw . When he looked for her, he could not find her.
piyisk itohtêw itêh mânah kâ-nikohtêyit . At last he went to where she used to gather faggots.

wâpahtam êsa nâpêwah êh-kîh-takohtêyit , êsah ê-mâsihitoyit , kâ-wâpahtahk ostêsah wîpisisiyiw êy-astêyik ê-mihkôwiyik , kâ-wâpahtahk itah êsah êh-ati-pimohtêyit ôwîkimâkanah , êh-sipwêhtêyit . [no translation] and then he saw his brother's arrow lying there, covered with blood, and he saw where his wife had walked, as she went away.
mihkoh êh-at-ah-astêyik , ma-mitihtêw . He followed her trail where the blood at intervals was on the ground.
piyisk nôhtaw tipiskâyiw . At last it grew dark before he had done.
êkos îsi kîwêw , êh-takohtêt wîkiwâhk . So he went back and came to their dwelling.
êkwah kotawêw , êh-ay-apit . Then he built a fire and stayed there.
mistahi mihtâtêw owîkimâkanah , ê-nakatikot . He grieved much for his wife, who had left him.
piyisk takohtêwak kahkiyaw oskinîkiwak ; namoya takohtêw awah macihkiwis . Finally all the young men arrived; only Matchihkiwis did not arrive.
oskinîkiwak namoya wâpamêwak ôhi wîtimowâwa . The young men did not see their brother's wife.

ômis îtêw :
nisîm , tâniwâ nîtim ? itwêwak . One said to him, “Brother, where is my sister-in-law?” Thus they asked.
namoya nikiskêyimâw , itwêw aw ôskinîkiw ; “I do not know,” said that youth;

seg.gloss: “to my surprise, when I came home, she was not here;
and when I sought her, I did not find her.
Then I went to where she is in the habit of gathering wood;

seg.q: pôtih niwâpahtên êsah êkotah ê-kih-takohtêt kstêsinaw , êsah kâh-mâsihât wîtimwa .
seg.gloss: there I saw that our oldest brother had come [no translation]
At last I saw an arrow of our brother's lying there.
It was covered with blood.
Then, it appeared, your sister-in-law had gone away.
I trailed her;

p.seg: mihkoh at-âh-astêw , itah êh-pimohtêt , piyisk kâ-pê-kîwêyân , itwêw aw oskinîkiw . there was blood every little ways, where she had walked, but at last I came home,” said that youth. CHECK heaviness of sandhi'd reduplication
hêhêhêy ! itwêwak ôk ôskinîkiwak ; “Heavens and earth!” said those young men;
mâka mîn êcik ânih êkâh katawah tiyôtahk kistêsinaw ! itwêwak . “And so again our eldest brother has been guilty of unseemly conduct!” they said.
mihtâtamwak ê-sipwêhtêyit ôh îskwêwah . They were sorry that that woman had gone away.
namoya wîh-mîcisôwak , ê-sipwêhtêyit ôh îskwêwa . they did not care to eat, because that woman had gone away.
mistahi êh-tipiskâyik , êkoyikohk kâ-takohtêt awa macihkiwis . When it was entirely dark, then Matchihkiwis arrived.
êh-pîhtokêt , wâpamêw êh-kâmwâtapiyit kahkiyaw osîmah . When he came in, he saw that all his brothers were sitting in dejection.
nisîm , tanêhki êkâ k-ôh-apit nîtim ? itwêw . “Brother, why is my sister-in-law not here?” he asked.
â , tânihk êtokê ? mâskôc nânitaw êh-itohtêt , itwêw aw oskinîkiw . “I wonder why. Perhaps she has gone somewhere or other,” said that youth.
êhêhêy hêhe ! itwêw macihkiwis ; “Heavens and earth!” cried Matchihkiwis;

wîsta mihtâtam , tâpiskôc êkâ nânitaw êh-kîh-tôtahk ; ayîsk mohcôwiw awa mâcihkiwis . he was too sorry, just as though he had had nothing to do with it; for this Matchihkiwis was a crazy sort of person.
piyisk namoya nipâwak , êh-mihtâtâcik ôh îskwêwa . When the time came, they did not sleep, what with their grief for that woman.
piyisk wâpaniyiw . At last day broke.
wawêyîw aw oskinîkiw . That youth made himself ready.
âh hâw , nistêsitik , niwîh-nitonawâw kîtimowâw , itwêw . “So now, brothers, I am going to look for your sister-in-law,” he said.
êhag , itwêwak oskinîkiwak . “Yes,” said the young men.
êkosi êkwah sipwêhtêw ôw oskinîkiw , êh-mitihtât owîkimâkanah , êh-pimohtêt . So then that youth set out to track his wife, and walked on.
êkwah ôki oskinîkiwak pêyakwanohk apiwak ; And the other young men stayed where they were;
namoya wîh-mâcîwak , êh-pakwâtahkik ê-sipwêhtêyit ôh îskwêwah , êh-mihtâtâcik . they did not care to hunt, for they were grieved that that woman had gone away and were sad at her absence.

êkwah aw ôskinîkiw kâ-ma-mitihtât owîkimâkanah , piyisk namoya wâpahtam itah êh-pimohtêyit êsa ; But that youth who was tracking his wife, at last came to a point where he could not see the signs of where she had walked;
tâpiskôc êh-ohpihâyit itêyihtam . it seemed to him just as if she had risen from the ground and taken wing.
pôtih êkotah nîpawiw , êh-nanâtawâpit . He stood there and looked about him.
tânitah ta-kîh-itohtêyit owîkimâkanah namoya kiskêyihtam . He did not know where his wife had gone.
nitawâc otinam omistanipîwayân , êh-pôtâtahk . Knowing no other way, he took a hair of fur and blew upon it.

seg.q: hâw , tântêh niwîkimâkan êh-itohtêt , êkotê nik-êtâsin !
seg.gloss: “Now, whithersoever my wife is bound, thither shall I be wafted!

p.seg: nik-ômistanipîwayâniwin ! itwêw . I shall be a hair of fur!” he said.
tâpwê ispimihk itâsiw . And truly, he was borne aloft by the wind.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk êh-asinîwacîwiyik . Presently he saw where there was a rocky cliff.
êkotê tahkohcâyihk kâ-pônâsit . There, at the summit, he was put down by the breeze.
êkosi êkotah êh-pasikôt , kâ-wâpahtahk itah êsah ê-kîh-pimohtêyit owîkimâkanah . Thereupon, when he rose to his feet, he saw again where his wife had walked.

êkwah êh-mitihtât , êy-ispatinâyik êh-ati-takohtêyit , ê-sâkêwêt , kâ-wâpahtahk ê-misâyik ôtênaw . Then, when he trailed her, and came to a rise in the land, as he came round to the other side, there he behld a large town.
wâpamêw ê-mihcêtiyit ayîsiyiniwah . He saw many people.
êkotah nahapiw . There he sat down.
piyisk kinwês êkotah apiw , ê-ka-kitâpahtahk ôhi mîkiwâhpah . He sat there for a long time, looking at all the tipis.
kîtahtawê kâ-pêcâstamohtêyit iskwêwah . Presently a woman came walking his way.
kisiwâk êh-pêy-ihtâyit , kâ-nisitawêyimât owîkimâkana . When she had come nearer, he recognized his wife.
mistahi miywêyihtam êh-pê-takohtêyit . He was very happy when she came.

sêmâk ocêmik ,
tâpwê nimiywêyihtên êh-takohtêyin , êh-itikot ; At once she kissed him, and, “Truly, I am glad that you have come,” she said to him;
ayîsk kakêpâtisiw kistês , k-ôh-pê-sipwêhtêyân , itik . “You must know it is because your eldest brother is senseless that I went away and have come here,” she told him.
tânisi êh-tôtâsk nistês ? itwêw . “What did my eldest brother do to you?” he asked.

seg.q:
anima kâ-mâciyêk , ê-ntawih-nikohtêyân , êkotah kâ-pê-takohtêt kistês , omis êy-isit :
êh-miywêyimitân , êy-isit .
seg.gloss: “At that time, when you were hunting, and I was going out to gather wood, to that place came your brother, and said to me, [no translation].
[no translation]

seg.q: mâka k-êtêyihtaman namoya wiya êwako ta-kîh-êkos-îspayiw , nititâw .
seg.gloss: [no translation]
[no translation]
[no translation]
[no translation]
[no translation]

seg.q: piyisk êkâh ê-kîh-sâkohit , kâ-pimot ôtah nipwâmihk .
seg.gloss: [no translation]
Then, off he went.

seg.q: êkosi ê-kîh-otinamân anima acosis ; êkotah aspin ntastân .
seg.gloss: So then I drew out that arrow; I laid it there, as I went away.

p.seg: nisâkihâ niwîkimâkan , kâ-nêpêwihit nîtim , nitêyihtên , nicawâc kâ-pê-kîwêyân , itwêyiwa . ‘I love my husband,’ was my thought, ‘but his brother has put me to shame,’ and so I needs came back here,” she said.
hâw , êh-pê-nâtitân , itik . “And now, I have come to get you,” she told him.
êkosi êkwah kîwêwak . Then they went to her home.
êh-takohtêcik mîkiwâhpihk , miywêyihtamiyiwah ôh âyîsiyiniwa . When they reached the tipi, those people were glad.

pôtih pîhtêyisk êh-cimatêyik êh-misâyik mîkiwâhp , êkotah kâ-takohtêcik , êh-pîhtokêcik , kâ-wâpamât oskinîkiskwêwa ê-mihcêtiyit . It was a large tipi which stood in the centre of all, to which they came, and, when they entered, there he saw a great many young women.

ê ê iy ! itwêyiwah ;
kîtimonaw takosin ! k-êtwêyit , êh-nahapit . “Why!” they cried; “Our brother-in-law has come!” they cried, as he took his seat.
êkwah ah-âtamiskâk . Then they all greeted him.

omisi itwêw awa kisêyiniw :
êhêhêy ! itwêw ; Thus spoke that old man: “Dear me!” he said;

âyisk , ninahâhkisîm , kakêpâtisiw kistês , ôhih kâ-tôtawât wîtimwa , ôh-pêh-kakwâtakihtayin , êh-pêy-itohtêyin , itwêw ; “Surely, your oldest brother is foolish to have treated his sister-in-law in this wise, so that you had to suffer much hardship in coming here,” he said;

hâw , êh-kitimâkisiyêk , êkâh awiyak êh-pamihikoyêk , kâ-kîh-itisahwak nitânis ,
ntawi-pamis ôk ôskinîkiwak , êh-itak , kâ-kîh-itohtêt , kâ-kakêpâtisit kistês , itwêw awa kisêyiniw ; “See, because you were pitiable, having no one to care for you, was why I sent my daughter there, saying to her, ‘Go take care of those young men,’ and so she went, and then your brother played the fool,” said the old man; CHECK ntawi-pamis
mâka nimiywêyihtên ê-takosiniyan , itwêw . “But I am glad you have come to us,” he said.
êkotah ay-ayâw aw oskinîkiw . There stayed that youth.
kêtahtawê mânah sipwêhtêw , ispatinâhk mâna êh-ay-apit , ê-ka-kitâpahtahk mîkiwâhpah . Then, in time, he would go away and sit on a hilltop and look at all the tipis.
piyis mâna takohtêyiwa owîkimâkanah êkotê ispatinâhk . After a while his wife would come to him there on the hilltop.
piyis kaskêyihtam , ostêsah êkâ h-wâpamât , osâm kinwês êkotêh êh-ayât . At last he grew sad, because he did not see his brothers, having been there so long.

kîtahtawê konitah ê-sa-sipwêhtêt , kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk , itah êh-pasahcâyik , ê-sakâyik , êkotah kâ-wâpahtahk môhkiciwanipêk , êh-miywâsiniyik asiskiy , tâpiskôc wiyaman k-êsinâkwaniyik . Then at one time, when he went off at random, he came to a wooded ravine and there saw a spring, and some good clay which looked exactly like vermilion.

otinam , êh-miywêyihtahk , oskotâkâhk êh-âh-ayîsihtitât , êkwah ostikwânihk , tâpiskôc êh-tômihkwêt êh-itêyihtahk . He took some, because he liked it, and placed it here and there on his coat, and on his head, thinking to himself that it was just as though he were painting his face.
êkos îsi êh-kîwêt . In that guise he went home.

êh-takohtêt wîkiwâhk , êh-pîhtokêt , ê-kitâpamikot ôh îskwêwah wîtimwah , cêmâk kâ-pâhpiyit ,
mnâ ! êh-itikot ,
mâmaskâc awa iyikohk wîh-mihkôwiw , êh-piyasîh-minahot ! k-êtikot . When he reached their dwelling, when he entered, and those women, his wife's sisters, looked at him, “A strange sight, the way he gets himself full of blood, when he has killed all the game he likes!” they said to him.
hay hay hay ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw . “Splendid! Splendid!” exclaimed the old man.

ômis îtwêw ôw oskinîkiw :
namoya kêkway ninipahâw , itwêw . The youth said, “I have not killed any kind of creature.”
nâh , êh-minahoyan , ôma mistahi kâ-mihkôwiyan ! itik wîwa . “Why, surely it was in killing some game that you got yourself all full of blood like this!” his wife told him.
êkosi otinamiyiwa nipiy , ê-kisîpêkinamiyit om oskotâkay mînah ostikwân . Then she took some water and washed his coat for him and his head.
mâmaskâc awa iyikohk ê-wîh-mihkowit ! itwêyiwa . “A strange sight, the way he gets himself covered with blood!” she said.
êkosi k-âti-wayawît awa kisêyiniw . Then the old man went out of the tipi.

seg.gloss: “Come, come, my followers, make yourselves ready!
Let us fetch meat from the killing!

p.seg: ninahâhkisîm nipahêw onîcâniwa ê-wîcêwâyit ocawâsimisiyiwa ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw . My son-in-law has killed a dam with her young!” cried the old man.
êkosi wawêyîwak . At that they made ready.
hâw , nitânis , ta-kiskinôhtahiwêw ninahâhkisîm , itwêw . “Come, daughter, let my son-in-law show the way,” he said.

êkosi aw oskinîkiw ômis îtwêw :
namoya kêkway ninipahâw , itâw owîkimâkana . Then that youth said, “I have not killed any kind of creature,” he told his wife.

ômah , itik ,
tânitah êy-ôhtinaman , ômah ‘asiskiy ’ k-êtwêyin , êkotah k-êtohtêyin ? itik owîkimâkana ; “But this,” she said to him, “where did you get it, this, which you call ‘clay,’ at the place to which you went?” his wife asked him;
ayîsiyiniwak cîw oma êh-itêyimiyâhk ? k-êtikot owîkimâkana . “And do you think we are human beings here?” she asked him.
êhag , itwêw aw oskinîkiw . “Yes,” said that youth.

seg.q:
awa kâ-nipahat k-êtikawiyan ,
misi-kinêpik , k-êtwêyêk , êkotôwa .
seg.gloss: “That creature which they tell you you have slain, when you say ‘Great Serpent,’ such it is.

p.seg: itah êh-ayât ôm âsiskiy kâ-pêtâyan , omihkoh niyân nititwânân , itik owîkimâkana . That clay which you have brought from where it is, we call it that creature's blood,” his wife told him.
êkosi êkwah sipwêhtêwak , êkotê êh-itohtahât ôh âyîsiyiniwah . So then they set out, that mortal man leading them thither.
kahkiyaw wîcêwêw owîtimwah . All his wife's sisters went with him.

ê-takohtêcik êkotê , ômisi itwêyiwa osisah :
hâw , nitân , ninahâhkisîm kanawêyim , êkâh ta-sêkihikot ôhih kâ-wîw-otinâyit ominahôwina , itwêyiwa . When they got there, his father-in-law said, “Now, daughter, take care of my son-in-law, that he be not frightened by those who are about to take up the game he has killed,” said he.

êkosi owîkimâkana otinik , tâpiskôc êh-apisîsisit , êkos ê-tôtâkot , otihkôkaniyihk êkotah êh-ahikot . Thereupon his wife picked him up; as if he were but a small creature she handled him, and placed him under her arm.

êkoyikohk ,
êkwah namoy âyîsiyiniwak ! itêyihtam , kahkiyaw êh-papâmihâyit ; At that, “No, they are not mortals!” he thought, as they all began to fly about;

êkwah piyêsiwak ! owîkimâkanah mîna , êh-misi-kimiwaniyik , mistah êh-kitôyit piyêsiwa , tâpiskôc kêkway êh-pâskisamiyit , mistah êh-na-namipayiyik askiy , êh-itêyihtahk . “And so they are Thunderers!” as his wife joined them, and there came a great rain, and the Thunderers roared loud, as if they were shooting some object, and the earth trembled much, as it seemed to him.

êh-pôni-pêhtâkosiyit , êkwah êh-otinikot ôwîkimâkanah , kâ-wâpamât ê-misikitiyit kinêpikwah êkwah pêyak êh-âpisîsisiyit . When they had ceased their noise, and his wife took him forth, there he saw a Great Serpent and a small one.
mâmaskâtam itah êy-ôhtinâyit mohkiciwanipêkohk , ê-kîh-wâpamât . It seemed strange to him that they had got those creatures from the spring, when he saw them.
nitânis , kîwêhtah ninahâhkisîm , itwêw awa kisêyiniw ; “Daughter, take my son-in-law home,” said the old man;
ka-pakwâtam , kinwêsk kitâpamâcih ôhi kinêpikwah , êh-itêyihtahk awa kisêyiniw . “It will not agree with him to look too long at these serpents,” was the old man's thought.
êkosi kîwêhtahêw owîkimâkanah aw iskwêw , aspin êh-wiyinihtâkêyit . So that woman took her husband home, as the others began to cut up the kill.
êkosi wiyawâw wîkiwâhk takohtêwak . So they arrived at their dwelling.
mînisah mîcisôwak owîkimâkana . He and his wife ate berries.
kîtahtawê kâ-takohtêyit , êkwah êh-pêtâyit wiyâs , itêyihtam . Presently the others arrived, bringing meat, as it seemed to him.

hâ , ntânis , spatinâhk ntawih-ay-apik , itwêw awa kisêyiniw , ômisi êh-itêyihtahk
kîsitêpowihkih , wîh-mîcisowihcih , ta-pakwâtam ninahâhkisîm , êh-itêyihtahk ; “Now, daughter, go you two, and stay on the hilltop,” said the old man, thinking, “When the cooking is being done, and when we eat our meal, it will be painful for my son-in-law,”
ayisk ôhi misi-kinêpikwah ê-wîh-môwâcik , êyok ohci k-ôh-itât onahâhkisîma . for they were going to eat that Great Serpent; that was why he said this of his son-in-law.
piyisk kinwêsk êkotê ayâw aw oskinîkiw , piyêsiwah êh-wîcêwât . For a long time, finally, that youth stayed there, with the Thunderers.

êkwah ômis îtwêw awa kisêyiniw :
nitânis , êkwah kîwêk . Then thus spoke that old man: “Daughter, now go home.

seg.q: ninahâhkisîm mistahi kitimâkisiyiwa ostêsah , êh-kaskêyihtamiyit , êkâ êh-wâpamikot .
seg.gloss: My son-in-law's brothers are very unhappy with grieving because they cannot see him.
He is staying here too long.

p.seg: kikîh-itikonaw kâ-tipêyimikoyahk , êkâ în-âyîsiyiniwa ta-wîcêwâyahk ôtêh ispimihk , itwêw awa kisêyiniw . He told us who is our Master, that we are not to have mortal men for our companions here above,” said the old man.
miywêyihtam aw oskinîkiw . The youth was glad.

seg.gloss: “There, tomorrow we shall go home.”
[no translation]
[no translation]

p.seg: êh-isih-askôwîskotâtôyêk , ka-wîcêwâwâwak , itwêw . [no translation]
mistahi miywêyihtam ê-wîh-ntawih-onâpêmit awa macihkihkwêwis macihkiwisah , The Silly Maiden was very glad that she was to go take to husband that Matchihkiwis;

konta tahkih êh-pâhpit ,
pitanê kiyipah wâpahk ! êh-itêyihtahk macihkihkwêwis , ê-nôhtê-onâpêmit . she kept laughing a foolish laugh, and she thought, that Silly Maiden, “I wish tomorrow would hurry up!” for she was eager to have a husband.
êkosi êkwah êh-tipiskâyik , êh-kîh-nipâcik , êh-wâpaniyik , ê-kîh-mîcisocik , êkwah sipwêhtêwak . So then when night came, when they had slept, in the morning, after they had eaten, they set out.
awa macihkihkwêwis mitoni êh-miywâsiniyik oskotâkay , kont ê-sêwêpayiyik , miton êh-miyohot . Very fine was Silly Maiden's coat, jingling with bells all over, for she had put on much finery.

itah êh-asiwatâcik otayôwinisiwâwa omaskisiniwâwa , êkonih tahkonamwak , ê-sipwêhtêcik . Those things into which they put their clothes and their moccasins, they carried in their hands, as they set out. LB after {omaskisiniwâwa,}: Narrator avoids the word {asiwacikan}.
piyis takohtêwak ôm îtah kâ-kîh-ohci-pimohtêt aw oskinîkiw . In time they came to the place from which that youth had walked.
namwâc wâpahtam askiy , nîhcâyîhk êh-itâpit . He could not see the earth, when he looked down below.
êkotah nîpawiwak . There they stood.

hâw , niwîkimâkan , itik ,
âstam ! “Now then, my husband,” she said to him, “come here!”

êh-nahikâpawistawât , otinik , tâpiskôc êh-âpisîsisit êh-tôtâkot , otihkôkaniyihk êkotah êh-ahikot , kâ-pêhtawât êh-kâ-kitôyit piyêsiwah . When he came and stood close to her, she took him up, handling him as though he were but a small creature, and placed him under her arm, and then he heard the Thunderers' repeated call.
êyakonik ôk ôskinîkiskwêwak , êkwah êy-ohpihâcik , êh-pimpahci-pêhtâkosicik , piyêsiwak . It was those young women, who now rose and took wing, and as Thunderers went speeding on with noise.
piyisk nîhcâyîhk takosinwak . Soon they arrived below.

itah kâ-wîkicik oskinîkiwak , cîk êkotah êh-twêhocik , kâwi ayîsiyiniwiwak ôk îskwêwak . When close to the dwelling place of those young men they landed from their flight, those women again took human form.

êkosi êkwah êh-pimohtêcik , mistahi miywêyihtam aw oskinîkiw ,
êkwah nistêsak cit-âyâwêwak iskwêwah , êh-itêyihtahk . Then they walked on. That youth was glad to think, “And now my brothers will have wives.”

êkosi êh-pimohtêcik , kêkâc êh-takohtêcik , ômis îtwêw aw oskinîkiw :
ôtah pita ayâk ; wawêsîk ; tômihkwêk . Then as they walked along, when they had almost come to their destination, that youth said, “Stay here a while; deck yourselves out; paint your faces.
nka-nitawih-âcimostawâwak nistêsak , êh-itât ôh iskwêwah ; I shall go and tell my brothers,” he said to those women;
itâp ka-pê-wîhtamâtinâwâw , itêw . “I shall come back and tell you,” he said to them.
êkosi êh-ati-sipwêhtêt , wawêsîwak ôk iskwêwak . So them, when he had gone on, those women put on their ornaments.
awa macîhkîhkwêwis mistahi wawêsîw . That Silly Maiden decked herself out splendidly.
awah oskinîkiw êh-takohtêt wîkiwâhk , pôtih nam âwiyah itêyihtam . When the youth reached their dwelling, at first he thought there was no one there.
êh-pîhtokêt , kahkiyaw ostêsah kâ-pimisiniyit . When he entered, thee were all his brothers lying on their beds.
waniskâk , nistêsitik ; nitakosinin ! itêw . “Arise, brothers; I have come!” he said to them.
êw-ohpiskwêyit awa macîhkiwis , kâ-wâpamât osîma êh-apiyit . When Matchihkiwis raised his head, there he saw his brother.

seg.gloss: “Get up, brothers;

p.seg: kisîminaw takosin ! itwêw . our brother has come!” he cried.
tâpwê waniskâwak , êh-wâpamâcik osîmiwâwa . They arose, and saw their youngest brother.
mistahi nanâskomôwak . They were very thankful.

mâskôc kîh-misi-wanâtisiw , ê-kîh-itêyimâcik osîmiwâwa , namoya ohcih nânâpâcihôwak . Because they thought of their brother, “Likely he has gone to his destruction,” for that reason they took no care of themselves. ohci here may be negative

seg.gloss: “Come, brothers, wash your faces;
when you have washed your faces, tidy yourselves;
put on your good clothes;
I am bringing women, the sisters of your sister-in-law who went away.
As many as you are, so many are the women.

p.seg: ê-is-ôma-askôwiskotâtôyahk , êkosi kik-êsi-nahapîstâkôwâwak pîhtokêtwâwi , itwêw . In the order of our ages they will take their seat by your sides, when they enter,” he said. Better as ômê (ipc, ‘over here’)?
hâ , mistahi miywêyihtam awa macihkiwis , iskwêwah ê-wîh-ayâwât . Oh, very glad was Matchihkiwis that he was to have a woman.
êh-kîsi-nânapâcihoyit , kâ-wayawît aw oskinîkiw , êh-ntawih-nitômât ôh îskwêwah . When they had groomed themselves, that youth went out to go call the women.

êh-otihtât ,
tâpwê nama mayaw kitakohtân , itik owîkimâkana . When he came to where they were, “Truly, you are late in coming back,” his wife said to him.

seg.gloss: “Yes, for my brothers had much to do, grooming themselves.

p.seg:
aspin kâ-sipwêhtêyân , êkospi ohcih pêyakwanohk êh-apicik , namoya nânâpâcihôwak ,
mâskôc misi-wanâcihôw , ê-kîh-itêyimicik , êkâ mayaw êh-wâpamicik , itêw owîkimâkanah ; Ever since I went away, they have been staying in that one spot and have taken no care of their appearance, because, when they did not see me in time, they thought of me, ‘No doubt he has gone to his destruction,’” he told his wife;

hâw , nîtim , itêw ôh ômisimâwa ,
ôtê skwâhtêmihk ohtapiw nistês ; êko kiya kâ-wîh-wîcêwat . “Now then, sister-in-law,” he said to that eldest sister, “There by the door sits my oldest brother; he is the one with whom you will keep company.

seg.q: nâway kiyah kika-pîhtokân , kahkiyaw pîhtokêtwâwi ôkih kisîmak .
seg.gloss: You will enter last, when all your sisters here have entered.
Do not enter promptly.
Walk back and forth outside the door.

p.seg: ta-kakwê-ihkêyihtam nistês , itwêw ô oskinîkiw . Let us try to make my eldest brother suffer from hope deferred,” said that youth.
êhag , itwêw macihkihkwêwis . “Very well,” said the Silly Maiden.

seg.gloss: “Come!”

p.seg: êkwah sipwêhtêwak , tahk êh-pâhpit awa macihkihkwêwis , êh-miywêyihtahk ê-wîh-onâpêmit . Then they set out, Silly Maiden laughing all the while, glad that she was to have a husband.

êkwah ôk ôskinîkiwak êh-apicik , macîhkiwis awa tahk êh-paspâpit , kîtahtawê kâ-pêtisâpamât , pêyak kâ-wâpamât êh-miyosiyit êkwah êh-miyohoyit . And as those young men sat there, and Matchihkiwis kept peering out through the door, in time he saw them approach, and one he saw who was beautiful and wore the finest clothes.
piyisk takohtêyiwa , kâ-pêhtahkik ê-sêwêpayiyit awiyah . At last they arrived, and they heard how some one of them jingled as she moved.
ê-pîhtokêyit osîmimâwa , ê-nahapiyit , kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit wîtimowâw . When their youngest brother entered and took his seat, in came their sister-in-law.
hay hay hay hay ! itwêwak oskinîkiwak , ê-nisitawêyimâcik wîtimowâwa . “Splendid, splendid!” cried the young men, when they recognized their sister-in-law.
êkotah êkwah kotakah kâ-pîhtokêyit , awa oskinîkiw cîk-ôsîmimâw ê-nahapîstâkot . And then another came in, and she took her seat by the side of the youth who was next to the youngest.
êkotah ohci âskaw pîhtokêyiwah , êh-ati-nahapîstâkocik . After that they came in at short intervals, and each one sat down by a young man.
piyisk kahkiyaw pîhtokêwak . At last they had all come in.
awa pikoh macihkihkwêwis namoya wîh-pîhtokêw . Only that Silly Maiden would not come in.

êkwah awa macîhkiwis êh-âyiwâkipayit , tahk êh-itâpit iskwâhtêmihk , êh-asawâpamât , ta-pîhtokêyit iskwêwah mêtwê-âhtohtêyicih kâ-sêwêpayiyit . And so Matchihkiwis was left as the odd one, and he kept looking at the doorway, looking out for the woman to enter, who could be heard walking up and down with her clothes a-jingling.
piyisk pîhtokêyiwa . At last she came in.
wahwâ , miyohoyiwa ! Hah, she was beautifully clad!
êh-nahapîstâkot macihkiwis , mistahi miywêyihtam . When she sat down by Matchihkiwis' side, he was delighted.
kahkiyaw êkwah ayâwêwak iskwêwah , kontah êh-pâ-pîkiskwêcik , êh-âcimocik , êh-pâhpicik . So now all of them had wives, and they talked and talked and jabbered, and told stories, and laughed.

kîtahtawê omisi k-êtwêt macihkiwis :
yâw , nisîmitik , tân om êtapiyêk ? Presently Matchihkiwis said, “Why, brothers, why do you sit here like this?
kinahâhkapihtânaw ! itwêw . Do not forget we are newly married!” he said.
otinam kaskaskisiw , ê-sikwatahahk , êh-tômihkwêt , êkw ê-kaskitêwikanakâpit ôtah oskîsikohk . He took some charcoal, ground it up, and painted himself, blackening his face round the eyes.

otinam opakamâkan , êh-ati-wayawît , otah kisiwâk êh-piskwahcâyik , êkotah êh-pa-pakamahikêt ; He took his club and went out of the tipi, and where, close by, there was a small knoll in the land, he knocked with his club;
kontah kâ-matwê-ma-mawimowit wâkayôsah , nipahêw . then he heard the growling of a bear; he killed it.
kîwêhtahêw ; pîhtokahêw . He took it back to the lodge with him; he brought it inside.

seg.gloss: “Here, this is for you, my wife!

p.seg: ômis êtokê kiwîh-ay-itahcikân êtokê , êh-têyihtaman , k-ôh-pê-wîkimiyan , itwêw macihkiwis . I daresay you were looking forward to this kind of food when you decided to come here and marry me,” said Matchihkiwis.
hay hay ! tâpwê nimiywêyihtên wâkayôs ê-wîh-môwak , itwêw macihkihkwêwis . “Oh, fine! Truly, I am glad that I am to eat bear's meat,” said the Silly Maiden.
êkosi êh-wiyinihtâkêt êkwah êh-pakâsimât wâkayôsa , kahkiyaw êyakonik êh-môwâcik . So then she cut up the bear and put it in the kettle, and they all ate of it.
êkwah êh-kîh-mîcisocik , êkoyikohk tipiskâyiw , ê-kîh-nipâcik . When they had eaten, it was dark, and so they went to bed.
êkwah tahto-kîsikâw mâcîwak , êh-pêtâcik wiyâs . Then they hunted every day and brought home the meat.
mistahi ka-kâyawisiwak ôk îskwêwak . Very industrious were those women.
mistah êh-atoskêcik , kiyipah wîkiwâwa kîsihtâwak ; They worked hard and soon had made their tipis;
kahkiyaw êkwah pâh-pêyakokêwak . so then they lived each in a separate tent.
mitâtaht osîhtâwak wîkiwâwa . they made ten tipis.
êkosi aspin êh-wâ-wîkicik . And so they lived there from that time on.
êkoyikohk êh-iskwâk âtayôhkêwin . This is where the sacred story ends.
